clinical_study.brief_title: Neurolyser XR Safety and Efficacy for the Ablation of the Lumbar Medial Branch Nerve
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Trial For - Safety and Efficacy of Using the Neurolyser XR Device for the Ablation of Neural Tissue of the Lumbar Medial Branch Nerve

brief_summary.textblock: Single arm pilot study to evaluate the safety and initial feasibility of the Neurolyser XR, a high intensity focused ultrasound device, for non-invasive treatment of axial chronic low back pain

detailed_description.textblock:
Study design: Prospective, single arm Timeline: nine month enrollment period and 12 months follow-up period. Sites: The study will be conducted at 10 sites in up to ten USA Study population: Thirty adult subjects diagnosed with facet related low back pain with an additional 10 roll in subjects.
Primary study objective: Safety and efficacy of the Neurolyser XR for the treatment of chronic low back pain secondary to zygapophyseal joint syndrome.
Safety is measured by the incidence and severity of treatment related adverse events.
Efficacy is measured by MRI imaging .

primary_outcome.description: Existence and size of edema or ablation as seen via changes in pre procedure MRI vs. post procedure MRI

primary_outcome.time_frame: Base line, 2 days 1, 2 & 4 weeks, 3 & 6 months after procedure
primary_outcome.description: Change in average pain score as measured by a numeric rating scale from 0 (no pain) to 10, worst possible pain

primary_outcome.measure: Procedure and Device Safety up to six months post procedure
primary_outcome.description: Safety will be measured by the incidence and severity of treatment related adverse events

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time Frame: Base line, 1, & 4 weeks, 3 & 6 months after procedure
Time Frame: Base line, 1, & 4 weeks, 3 & 6 months after procedure
secondary_outcome.description: A multipurpose short form survey with 12 questions (Range: 0 to 100)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time Frame: Base line, 1, & 4 weeks, 3 & 6 months after procedure
secondary_outcome.description: Patient Global Impression of Change (Range: 1 to 7)

arm_group.arm_group_label: Thermal ablation of the medial nerve branch using High Intensity Focused Ultrasound
arm_group.description: Non-Invasive Thermal Ablation of the Medial Branch Nerves using the Neurolyser XR High Intensity Focused Ultrasound device

intervention.intervention_name: Non-Invasive Thermal Ablation of the Medial Branch Nerves (Neurolyser XR)
intervention.description: Thermal ablation of the medial nerve branch using High Intensity Focused Ultrasound
intervention.arm_group_label: Thermal ablation of the medial nerve branch using High Intensity Focused Ultrasound

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age 50 to 85 years old, legally able and willing to participate in the study and all follow-up visits
2. Able and willing to complete the research questionnaires, follow instructions, push the halt button and to communicate with investigator and research team
3. Patient with bilateral or unilateral low back pain of > 6 months duration
4. Patients whose back pain is alleviated by recumbency or comfortable sitting position
5. Patients presenting with a) a positive (>80% pain relief) to a previous, double, L1 to L5 (down to sacral-ala) lumbar medial branch block (within the last 12 months) and/or b) with a positive (>70% pain relief lasting more than 6 months) to a previous lumbar facet thermal radiofrequency enervation
6. Average low back pain score of 6 or higher in the last month (on 0-10 scale)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Pregnant or breastfeeding patient
2. Patients younger than 50 or older than 85 years
3. BMI greater than 40
4. Patients presenting with neurological deficits (including lumbosacral radiculopathy but not solitary radicular pain)
5. Patients with history of lumbosacral spine surgery excluding previous lumbar radiofrequency neurotomy
6. Patients who have had lumbar radiofrequency neurotomy in the past 6 months
7. Patients with the presence of metal hardware or other foreign objects at the lumbosacral spine
8. Patients with history of lumbar spine pathology that may increase procedural risk and/or influence symptoms and/or generate unrelated adverse event (per investigator's discretion)
9. Patients unable to understand and complete the research questionnaires in the official language used within the particular sites' location
10. Patients presenting with any severe medical condition preventing the patient from safely and effectively being treated in the study or reporting study outcomes (per investigator's discretion)
11. Patient with extensive scarring of the skin and tissue overlying the treatment area
12. Patients enrolled in or planned to be enrolled in another clinical trial during the duration of this research project
13. Any patients with an uncontrolled coagulopathy
14. Patients with known osteoporosis with absolute risk of spinal fracture of > 10% over 10 years
15. Any patients with a history of malignant disease in the past five years
16. Patients with rheumatologic diseases causing spine pain that are currently receiving active treatment including steroids, disease modifying drugs, biological agents or immunosuppressants
17. Patients known for concomitant psychiatric disorders, excluding mood disorders
18. Patients presenting with concomitant mood disorders (deemed severe by the research physician)
19. Patient with first-degree family member already enrolled in this study
20. Patient who is scheduled for any interventional/surgical procedure within 3 months from screening date
21. Patients diagnosed with co-morbid multifocal chronic pain (e.g. fibromyalgia)
22. Patient is not able to undergo MRI with contrast
23. Patient has a primary source of pain that is 2 or more points higher on the NRS score than the patients low back pain
24. Patient has had a steroid injection within the last 2 months from date of enrollment at the location of the planned treatment
